Literature Review: The control of breathing is a complex physiological process that has been the subject of extensive research due to its critical role in maintaining homeostasis and its multifunctionality in response to various internal and external stimuli. The advent of molecular tools has significantly advanced our understanding of the neural circuits involved in breathing control, particularly within the brainstem. This literature review explores the contributions of recent molecular and cellular studies to our understanding of the diversity of neuronal types in the breathing control circuit and how they confer the multifunctionality of breathing. The preBötzinger complex (preBötC) has been identified as a critical site for the generation of respiratory rhythm. Studies utilizing optogenetics and chemogenetics have demonstrated that specific neuronal populations within the preBötC are essential for the generation and modulation of respiratory rhythm, highlighting the complexity of the neural network involved in breathing control (Smith et al., 1991; Feldman et al., 2013). The nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) plays a pivotal role in integrating sensory information from the lungs and other visceral organs to modulate breathing. Molecular studies have elucidated the role of various neurotransmitters and receptors within the NTS in mediating the Hering-Breuer reflex, a protective mechanism that prevents overinflation of the lungs (Kubin et al., 2006; Bonham et al., 2006). Serotonin (5-HT) has been implicated in the modulation of respiratory activity, with studies showing that 5-HT neurons in the medulla can influence the activity of the preBötC and other respiratory centers. The use of molecular tools has allowed researchers to dissect the specific contributions of 5-HT receptor subtypes to respiratory control, providing insights into the mechanisms underlying the modulation of breathing by serotonin (Hodges & Richerson, 2010; Ray et al., 2011). Furthermore, the integration of breathing with other orofacial behaviors such as speech, chewing, and swallowing has been explored through molecular studies, revealing the complex interplay between respiratory and non-respiratory neural circuits (Barlow & Estep, 2006; Ludlow, 2005). The perception of breathing intensity and its impact on emotional states has also been investigated, with molecular tools providing a deeper understanding of the neural mechanisms linking respiratory sensations to affective processes (Evans, 2010; Homma & Masaoka, 2008). In conclusion, the transformation of our understanding of breathing control by molecular tools has unveiled the intricate neural circuits and diverse neuronal types that confer the multifunctionality of breathing. These advances have not only deepened our appreciation of the complexity of respiratory control but also opened new avenues for the development of therapeutic interventions for respiratory disorders.
